unnormalised: Arre yaar, load shedding! Isn't that the bane of every Indian's existence? Especially during the scorching Delhi summers, when you're just settling in for an evening binge-watching "Sholay" on Netflix and BAM! Darkness. Your inverter sputters its last breath, and you're left sweating like a samosa in a tandoor.

unnormalised: Load shedding, or planned power cuts, is basically when the electricity company, like Tata Power DDL, deliberately cuts off power supply to certain areas to prevent the entire grid from collapsing. Think of it like this: the power grid is like a big thali of food, and everyone's grabbing for more. If too many people grab at once, the thali will topple, right? Load shedding is the electricity board's way of making sure the "thali" doesn't fall.

Load shedding is the electricity board's way of making sure the "thali" doesn't fall.

unnormalised: But why does this happen, you ask? Well, there are a few reasons. Sometimes it's because the demand for electricity is simply higher than the supply. Especially during peak hours, like evenings when everyone's home from work and switching on their ACs, the power plants can struggle to keep up. Other times, it's due to infrastructure issues. Maybe a transformer blows up somewhere in Meerut, or a power line gets damaged during a monsoon storm. These things happen, you know?

The National Power Training Institute (NPTI) is also working on training more skilled engineers to manage the grid more efficiently. But still, load shedding continues to be a reality, especially in smaller towns and rural areas.
